subject: Economics
courseTitle: Economic Crises That Shook the World

topics.title: Tulip Mania: The Flower That Cost More Than a House

hook.text: In 1637 Holland, a single tulip bulb sold for 10,000 guilders â€” enough to buy a luxury canal house in Amsterdam.

buildup.text: Tulips arrived from Turkey and became status symbols. Rare varieties with streaked petals commanded insane prices.

discovery.text: A futures market emerged â€” people traded contracts for bulbs still in the ground. Speculation replaced gardening.

twist.text: In February 1637, buyers stopped showing up at an auction. Within weeks, prices crashed 99%.

climax.text: Tulip mania is history's first recorded speculative bubble â€” and proof that humans will speculate on anything.

punchline.text: The first financial bubble was about flowers.

quiz.question: What triggered the collapse of tulip mania?
options: Buyers simply stopped appearing at auctions, causing a confidence collapse

topics.title: The South Sea Bubble: When a Nation Gambled

hook.text: In 1720, Isaac Newton lost Â£20,000 in the South Sea Bubble â€” roughly $4 million today.

buildup.text: The South Sea Company offered to take over Britain's national debt in exchange for a trade monopoly.

discovery.text: The company had almost no real trade. Its value was based on promises, bribery of politicians, and mass hysteria.

twist.text: Newton invested early, sold for a profit, then bought back in at the peak.

climax.text: The crash wiped out thousands. Parliament investigated but most corrupt officials were never punished. Sound familiar?

punchline.text: Newton said: 'I can calculate the motion of stars, but not the madness of men.'

quiz.question: Why did Isaac Newton lose money in the South Sea Bubble?
options: He sold for profit then reinvested at the peak, driven by fear of missing out

topics.title: The Mississippi Bubble: France's Paper Money Disaster

hook.text: John Law convinced France to replace gold with paper money backed by Louisiana's riches.

buildup.text: Law's Mississippi Company monopolized French trade. Its shares rose 2,000% in 1719.

discovery.text: Law printed money to keep share prices rising. France's money supply increased 16-fold. Inflation exploded.

twist.text: When a prince tried to convert his shares to gold, the system collapsed. France banned paper money for 80 years.

climax.text: Law's experiment proved that paper money works only if people trust it â€” and trust can evaporate in a single afternoon.

punchline.text: France's first paper money experiment was so bad they didn't try again for 80.

quiz.question: What ultimately caused the Mississippi Bubble to burst?
options: Investors tried to convert shares to gold, revealing the system couldn't honor its promises

topics.title: The Panic of 1907: The Crisis That Created the Fed

hook.text: In 1907, one man personally stopped a financial panic. J.P.

buildup.text: A failed attempt to corner the copper market triggered bank runs across New York. The stock market dropped 50%.

discovery.text: There was no central bank. Morgan assembled private bankers and forced them to pool money and save the banking system.

twist.text: Congress realized a 70-year-old private citizen shouldn't be the last line of defense.

climax.text: The 1907 panic proved that modern economies need a lender of last resort.

punchline.text: The Federal Reserve exists because one old banker couldn't live forever.

quiz.question: How did the 1907 panic lead to the Federal Reserve?
options: Relying on one private citizen (J.P. Morgan) to stop panics proved unsustainable

topics.title: The Railway Bubble: Victorian England's Tech Crash

hook.text: In the 1840s, Britain invested a third of GDP in railways. Many routes went nowhere.

buildup.text: Railways were the internet of the 1840s. Everyone believed they would transform everything â€” and invested accordingly.

discovery.text: Parliament approved 272 railway acts in 1846 alone.

twist.text: When profits didn't materialize, shares crashed. But the tracks remained.

climax.text: Bubble investors lose money, but society often keeps the infrastructure.

punchline.text: Bubbles destroy investors but sometimes build civilization.

quiz.question: What lasting benefit came from the Victorian railway bubble?
options: Britain gained an extensive rail network even though investors lost fortunes

topics.title: Black Tuesday: The Day the Roaring Twenties Died

hook.text: On October 29, 1929, the stock market lost 12% in a single day. $14 billion vanished â€” more than the US federal budget.

buildup.text: The 1920s were a party: stocks rose 300% in a decade.

discovery.text: When prices started falling, lenders demanded repayment.

twist.text: The market didn't hit bottom until 1932 â€” an 89% decline from the peak. It took 25 years to recover fully.

climax.text: Black Tuesday didn't cause the Depression.

punchline.text: The roaring twenties ended in a whisper of margin calls.

quiz.question: What amplified the 1929 stock market crash?
options: Margin lending forced investors to sell into a falling market, creating a downward spiral

topics.title: Bank Runs: When Trust Leaves the Building

hook.text: Between 1930 and 1933, 9,000 American banks failed. One in three.

buildup.text: A bank run starts when a few people withdraw cash. Others see the line and panic.

discovery.text: Bank runs are self-fulfilling prophecies.

twist.text: FDR created FDIC deposit insurance in 1933. Bank runs virtually stopped overnight.

climax.text: Deposit insurance costs the government almost nothing.

punchline.text: The cheapest insurance in history is the one that's never claimed.

quiz.question: Why did FDIC deposit insurance virtually eliminate bank runs?
options: Guaranteed deposits removed the incentive to panic-withdraw, preventing self-fulfilling crises

topics.title: The Dust Bowl: When Nature and Economics Collided

hook.text: In the 1930s, walls of dust 10,000 feet high swept across the Great Plains.

buildup.text: WWI wheat prices drove farmers to plow millions of acres of grassland.

discovery.text: The Dust Bowl wasn't a natural disaster â€” it was an economic one.

twist.text: 2.5 million people fled the Plains. 'Okies' migrated to California, where they were met with hostility and exploitation.

climax.text: The Dust Bowl showed that markets without environmental guardrails can destroy the natural capital on which all.

punchline.text: The market said: grow more wheat. Nature said: I quit.

quiz.question: What was the economic cause of the Dust Bowl?
options: Market incentives drove farmers to over-plow grassland, destroying topsoil with no environmental protections

topics.title: The New Deal: FDR's Economic Experiment

hook.text: When FDR took office in 1933, 25% of Americans were unemployed. He promised 'bold, persistent experimentation.

buildup.text: In his first 100 days, FDR created the CCC, WPA, SEC, FDIC, and Social Security.

discovery.text: The New Deal put millions to work building roads, dams, bridges, and parks. Many are still in use 90 years later.

twist.text: FDR cut spending in 1937, trying to balance the budget.

climax.text: The New Deal didn't fully end the Depression â€” WWII spending did.

punchline.text: The New Deal didn't cure the Depression. It proved the patient could survive.

quiz.question: What lesson came from the Roosevelt Recession of 1937?
options: Cutting government spending during a fragile recovery can cause the economy to crash again

topics.title: Smoot-Hawley: The Tariff That Deepened the Depression

hook.text: In 1930, the US raised tariffs on 20,000 imported goods. 1,028 economists signed a petition begging Congress not to.

buildup.text: The Smoot-Hawley Tariff was supposed to protect American jobs.

discovery.text: World trade collapsed by 65% between 1929 and 1934.

twist.text: Smoot-Hawley turned a US recession into a global depression.

climax.text: Trade wars don't protect economies â€” they shrink them.

punchline.text: 1,028 economists were right. Congress was wrong.

quiz.question: How did the Smoot-Hawley Tariff worsen the Great Depression?
options: Retaliatory tariffs collapsed global trade by 65%, deepening the worldwide downturn

topics.title: The 1973 Oil Shock: OPEC's Economic Weapon

hook.text: In October 1973, Arab oil producers cut production by 25% and banned exports to the US.

buildup.text: The US supported Israel in the Yom Kippur War. OPEC retaliated not with weapons but with oil â€” a far more powerful tool.

discovery.text: Americans waited hours in gas lines. Speed limits dropped to 55 mph.

twist.text: The crisis triggered 'stagflation' â€” simultaneous inflation and recession. Economists said this was impossible.

climax.text: The oil shock ended the postwar economic golden age.

punchline.text: A tap in Saudi Arabia controlled the American economy.

quiz.question: What unprecedented economic phenomenon did the 1973 oil shock trigger?
options: Stagflation â€” simultaneous inflation and recession

topics.title: Japan's Lost Decades: When a Miracle Became a Nightmare

hook.text: In 1989, the Imperial Palace grounds in Tokyo were worth more than all real estate in California.

buildup.text: Japan's stock market hit 38,957 in 1989. Property prices were surreal.

discovery.text: When the Bank of Japan raised rates, both markets crashed. The Nikkei fell 80%.

twist.text: Japan tried everything â€” zero interest rates, massive spending, quantitative easing. Nothing fully worked for 30 years.

climax.text: Japan's lost decades proved that some economic wounds don't heal quickly.

punchline.text: Japan's stock market took 34 years to reach its 1989 high again.

quiz.question: Why did Japan's economy stagnate for decades after 1989?
options: A massive asset bubble burst, and the resulting debt, deflation, and lost confidence persisted for 30+ years
Population decline was the sole cause

topics.title: The Savings and Loan Crisis: America's Forgotten Bailout

hook.text: In the 1980s, 1,043 American savings banks failed. The taxpayer bill: $132 billion.

buildup.text: Deregulation let savings institutions invest in risky real estate and junk bonds.

discovery.text: Moral hazard: when deposits are insured, banks take bigger risks. If they win, they profit. If they lose, taxpayers pay.

twist.text: The Keating Five scandal showed US senators protecting a failing banker in exchange for campaign donations.

climax.text: The S&L crisis was a dress rehearsal for 2008 â€” same deregulation, same moral hazard, same taxpayer bailout.

punchline.text: The 2008 crisis wasn't unprecedented. We just forgot the last time.

quiz.question: What role did moral hazard play in the S&L crisis?
options: Government deposit insurance let banks gamble with depositors' money â€” profits were private, losses public

topics.title: Black Monday 1987: The Algorithm Crash

hook.text: On October 19, 1987, the Dow Jones fell 22.6% in one day â€” still the largest single-day percentage drop in history.

buildup.text: New 'portfolio insurance' strategies used computers to automatically sell stocks when prices fell.

discovery.text: When prices dropped, the algorithms sold. That selling pushed prices lower, triggering more algorithmic selling.

twist.text: The market recovered within two years. No recession followed.

climax.text: 1987 was the first crisis caused by automated trading.

punchline.text: The first robot panic attack crashed the stock market.

quiz.question: What amplified the Black Monday crash of 1987?
options: Automated portfolio insurance algorithms created a feedback loop of selling

topics.title: The Long-Term Capital Management Collapse

hook.text: Two Nobel laureates built a hedge fund with 'risk-free' trading strategies.

buildup.text: LTCM used complex math to find tiny price differences and bet billions on them. Returns were 40% per year.

discovery.text: Russia's 1998 default triggered a global panic. LTCM's 'impossible' losses happened simultaneously across every market.

twist.text: LTCM's positions were so large that its failure would have frozen the global bond market. The Fed organized a $3.

climax.text: LTCM proved that mathematical models can't capture once-in-a-century events.

punchline.text: Two Nobel Prizes in finance couldn't prevent one spectacular failure.

quiz.question: What lesson did LTCM's collapse teach about financial models?
options: Models underestimate extreme events â€” 'impossible' scenarios happen more often than predicted

topics.title: Subprime Mortgages: The Loans That Blew Up the World

hook.text: Banks gave mortgages to people with no income, no job, and no assets. They called these NINJA loans.

buildup.text: Housing prices kept rising, so nobody cared about borrower quality.

discovery.text: Banks bundled risky mortgages into securities and sold them worldwide.

twist.text: When housing prices stopped rising, the entire logic collapsed. Defaults cascaded.

climax.text: The crisis wasn't just about bad loans. It was about a system where everyone profited from risk they passed to someone.

punchline.text: Banks lent to people who couldn't pay back because they didn't plan to hold.

quiz.question: Why were banks willing to issue risky subprime mortgages?
options: They could sell the risk to investors via securitization, keeping the profit without the consequences

topics.title: Lehman Brothers: The Bank That Was Allowed to Die

hook.text: On September 15, 2008, Lehman Brothers â€” 158 years old, $639 billion in assets â€” filed for bankruptcy.

buildup.text: The US government bailed out Bear Stearns in March. Markets assumed Lehman would get the same treatment.

discovery.text: Lehman's collapse triggered a chain reaction. Money markets froze. Banks stopped lending to each other.

twist.text: Hank Paulson let Lehman fail to avoid 'moral hazard.

climax.text: Lehman's failure proved that in an interconnected system, one death can trigger a pandemic.

punchline.text: The decision to let one bank die nearly killed them all.

quiz.question: What made Lehman Brothers' failure so devastating to the global economy?
options: Its interconnection with global markets caused credit to freeze worldwide in a chain reaction
It held most US government debt

topics.title: Credit Default Swaps: Insurance That Burned the House Down

hook.text: AIG sold $440 billion in insurance on mortgage bonds. When the bonds went bad, AIG couldn't pay.

buildup.text: Credit default swaps (CDS) let investors buy insurance on bonds they didn't own.

discovery.text: The CDS market grew to $62 trillion â€” unregulated, unreported, and larger than the entire world's GDP.

twist.text: When mortgages defaulted, CDS created obligations nobody could honor.

climax.text: CDS turned a housing crisis into a global financial crisis.

punchline.text: Wall Street insured itself against risk so thoroughly that it created a bigger.

quiz.question: How did credit default swaps worsen the 2008 crisis?
options: The unregulated $62 trillion CDS market amplified losses when mortgages defaulted, threatening the entire system

topics.title: Too Big to Fail: The $700 Billion Bailout

hook.text: In October 2008, the US government gave Wall Street $700 billion in taxpayer money.

buildup.text: TARP (Troubled Asset Relief Program) was supposed to buy toxic assets.

discovery.text: The bailout worked mechanically â€” it prevented total collapse.

twist.text: Bankers who caused the crisis received billions in bonuses from bailout money. Zero executives went to prison.

climax.text: 'Too big to fail' creates a perverse incentive.

punchline.text: Capitalism means profits are private. 'Too big to fail' means losses are public.

quiz.question: What moral hazard does 'too big to fail' create?
options: Banks take excessive risks knowing taxpayers will cover catastrophic losses

topics.title: The Eurozone Debt Crisis: When Austerity Backfired

hook.text: Greece revealed its deficit was 12.7%, not 3.7% as reported. European markets panicked.

buildup.text: The euro let countries like Greece borrow at German interest rates. They spent like Germany was backing the check.

discovery.text: Bailouts came with brutal austerity conditions: slash pensions, cut healthcare, raise taxes.

twist.text: Austerity was supposed to restore confidence.

climax.text: The euro crisis showed that a shared currency without shared fiscal policy creates crises no one can solve.

punchline.text: Europe shared a currency but not the bill. That was the problem.

quiz.question: Why did austerity measures worsen Greece's economic crisis?
options: Spending cuts crushed demand, deepened the recession, and made debt ratios worse

topics.title: The Asian Financial Crisis: Tiger Economies Humbled

hook.text: Thailand ran out of dollars on July 2, 1997. It floated the baht.

buildup.text: Asian 'tiger' economies grew explosively through the 1990s, funded by cheap foreign loans.

discovery.text: When the baht collapsed, dollar-denominated debts became unpayable.

twist.text: The IMF demanded austerity in exchange for bailouts.

climax.text: The Asian crisis showed that hot money â€” short-term foreign capital.

punchline.text: Foreign money built the tigers. Foreign money also ate them.

quiz.question: What was the core vulnerability that caused the Asian financial crisis?
options: Countries borrowed in foreign currencies, making debts unpayable when local currencies collapsed

topics.title: Argentina's Default: When a Country Goes Bankrupt

hook.text: In December 2001, Argentina defaulted on $95 billion in debt â€” the largest sovereign default in history at the time.

buildup.text: Argentina had pegged its peso 1:1 to the US dollar.

discovery.text: When the peg became unsustainable, the government froze bank accounts. Riots erupted.

twist.text: After defaulting and devaluing, Argentina's economy grew 63% in six years.

climax.text: Argentina proved that sovereign default isn't the end.

punchline.text: Going bankrupt was the best economic decision Argentina made.

quiz.question: What happened to Argentina's economy after its 2001 default?
options: The economy grew 63% over six years as default relieved the debt burden

topics.title: The Russian Default of 1998: From Reform to Ruin

hook.text: In August 1998, Russia defaulted on its domestic debt and devalued the ruble by 70%. Oligarchs got richer.

buildup.text: Russia's 'shock therapy' transition from communism created oligarchs who bought state assets for pennies.

discovery.text: The government funded itself with short-term bonds at 150% interest rates.

twist.text: Russia's default triggered the LTCM collapse in the US.

climax.text: The 1998 crisis showed that in globalized markets, no country's problems stay local.

punchline.text: A debt default in Moscow crashed a hedge fund in Connecticut.

quiz.question: How did Russia's 1998 default affect global markets?
options: It triggered the LTCM hedge fund collapse and global financial contagion

topics.title: Venezuela's Hyperinflation: Oil Wealth Destroyed

hook.text: Venezuela has the world's largest oil reserves. By 2019, 94% of its population lived in poverty.

buildup.text: ChÃ¡vez used oil revenues to fund social programs while hollowing out the national oil company and scaring away private.

discovery.text: When oil prices crashed in 2014, the government printed money instead of reforming.

twist.text: Venezuelans lost an average of 11 kilograms of body weight in 2017. The economy was so broken, people couldn't eat.

climax.text: Venezuela proves that natural resources aren't wealth. Institutions, governance, and economic diversity are.

punchline.text: The richest oil country on Earth couldn't feed its people.

quiz.question: Why did Venezuela's oil wealth lead to economic collapse?
options: Over-dependence on oil, institutional decay, and money printing created hyperinflation when oil prices fell
International sanctions were the sole cause

topics.title: The Dot-Com Bust: When the Internet Bubble Burst

hook.text: Pets.com raised $82 million in its IPO, selling dog food online at a loss. It went bankrupt in 268 days.

buildup.text: Between 1995 and 2000, the NASDAQ rose 400%. Any company with '.

discovery.text: Investors valued 'eyeballs' not profits. Amazon traded at 300x earnings. Webvan burned $1.

twist.text: The NASDAQ fell 78% by 2002. But companies that survived â€” Amazon, Google, eBay â€” became the most valuable in history.

climax.text: The dot-com bubble proved the technology was real but the valuations were fantasy.

punchline.text: The internet changed everything. That didn't make every internet company viable.

quiz.question: What was the lasting impact of the dot-com bust?
options: Overvalued companies died but survivors like Amazon became the most valuable companies ever

topics.title: COVID-19: The Fastest Economic Crash in History

hook.text: In March 2020, the global economy shut down in two weeks. US GDP fell 31.4% in Q2 â€” the steepest drop ever recorded.

buildup.text: Lockdowns halted supply and demand simultaneously. Restaurants, airlines, hotels, and retail collapsed overnight.

discovery.text: Governments responded with unprecedented stimulus: the US alone injected $5 trillion.

twist.text: Markets recovered in months while the real economy suffered for years.

climax.text: COVID proved governments can prevent depression through massive spending â€” but the bill comes later as inflation.

punchline.text: The cure for the fastest crash was the fastest money printing in history.

quiz.question: What was the 'K-shaped recovery' during COVID?
options: Some groups (tech workers) recovered quickly while others (service workers) continued struggling

topics.title: The Crypto Winter: When Digital Fortunes Melted

hook.text: In November 2021, crypto was worth $3 trillion. By the end of 2022, it had lost $2 trillion.

buildup.text: Celebrity endorsements, Super Bowl ads, and easy money fueled a speculative frenzy.

discovery.text: Terra/Luna collapsed in May 2022, erasing $45 billion in days.

twist.text: FTX's Sam Bankman-Fried was hailed as crypto's savior, then arrested for fraud.

climax.text: The crypto winter followed the classic bubble script: innovation â†’ mania â†’ fraud â†’ crash.

punchline.text: Every generation gets the South Sea Bubble it deserves.

quiz.question: What pattern did the 2022 crypto crash follow?
options: The classic bubble cycle: genuine innovation â†’ speculative mania â†’ fraud exposure â†’ crash

topics.title: Anatomy of Every Crisis: The Pattern That Never Changes

hook.text: Tulips 1637. Railways 1845. Stocks 1929. Housing 2008. Crypto 2022. Different assets, identical human behavior.

buildup.text: Charles Kindleberger mapped the universal crisis pattern.

discovery.text: Every bubble starts with a real innovation. Then leverage amplifies it. Then greed detaches prices from reality.

twist.text: Knowing the pattern doesn't prevent it. Participants in every bubble believe 'this time is different.' It never is.

climax.text: Financial crises are not failures of economics â€” they're features of human psychology.

punchline.text: The four most expensive words in economics: 'This time is different.'

quiz.question: According to Kindleberger, what is the universal pattern of financial crises?
options: Displacement â†’ credit expansion â†’ euphoria â†’ critical stage â†’ revulsion

topics.title: The Mexican Peso Crisis: The Tequila Effect

hook.text: In December 1994, Mexico devalued the peso by 50% in one week.

buildup.text: Mexico had pegged the peso to the dollar while running large deficits. Foreign money poured in, masking fragility.

discovery.text: When confidence broke, investors pulled $20 billion in weeks. The US organized a $50 billion emergency rescue.

twist.text: The crisis spread to Brazil and Argentina â€” the Tequila Effect. Markets learned emerging economies were linked.

climax.text: Mexico repaid the rescue early and reformed. The crisis proved that fixed exchange rates invite speculative attacks.

punchline.text: Peg your currency, and you peg your fate to confidence.

quiz.question: What is the 'Tequila Effect'?
options: Mexico's crisis spread to other Latin American economies
Alcohol consumption rose during the crisis

topics.title: The Supply Chain Crisis: When the World Jammed

hook.text: In 2021, a Toyota dealer sold used cars for more than new ones. A container ship blocked the Suez Canal.

buildup.text: COVID shut factories worldwide. When demand roared back, supply couldn't keep up.

discovery.text: Just-in-time manufacturing â€” keeping zero inventory â€” had made supply chains efficient but fragile.

twist.text: A single chip shortage idled auto plants globally. One factory in Taiwan controlled the world's car production.

climax.text: The crisis revealed globalization's hidden risk: efficiency and resilience are opposites. We chose efficiency.

punchline.text: The world's supply chain was a miracle â€” until one link broke.

quiz.question: What made global supply chains fragile?
